A 55 years old man presents to you with a 2 week history of pain in his hands. The pain is particularly bad in his right hand. On examination, brown discolouration of his nails with oncholysis is noted and the Distal interphalangeal joints are swollen and tender. What is the most likely diagnosis:

A 22-year-old man develops the insidious onset of low back pain improved with exercise and worsened by rest. There is no history of diarrhea, conjunctivitis, urethritis, rash, or nail changes. On examination, the patient has loss of mobility with respect to lumbar flexion and extension. He has a kyphotic posture.
